div.l: And by that light she sawe them bothe two
But sykerly she nyst who was who
And as she saw a white thing in her eye
And whan she can this white thing aspye
She wende the clerke hadde wered a volupere
And with the staf she drewe ay nere and nere
And haue hyt this aleyn at the fulle
And smote the myller on the pylde scul
And doun he goth and cryed harow I dye
The clerkes bete him wele and leet him lye
And dressed them and toke their horse anone
And eke their mele and on theire wey they gone
And at the mylle dore yet they toke theire cake
Of half a busshel floure wele y bake
Thus is the proude myller wele y bete
And hath y lost the gryndyng of the whete
And payed for the souper euerydele
Of aleyn and of Iohn that bete him wele
His wif is swyued and his doughter als
Lo suche it is a myller to be fals
And therto this prouerbe is sayde fulle soth
Him dare nat wene wele that euyl doth
A gylour shalle him selue begyled be
And god that sytteth high in mageste
Saue al the company grete and smale
Thus haue I quyte the myller in my tale
Here endyth the Reues tale
And here begynneth the Cokes prologue
THe Cooke of london while the reue spake
For ioye he thought he clawed him on the bake
